EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of:
• Two stone furnaces – one at Position(x=0.0, y=0.0) and another at Position(x=5.0, y=0.0) – each paired with nearby burner inserters (for example, one at Position(x=1.5, y=0.5)) and output chests (e.g. a wooden chest at Position(x=0.5, y=2.5)).  
• Interconnecting transport belts ensure efficient smelting operations.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of:
• A burner mining drill placed at Position(x=-15.0, y=-50.0) with associated inserters and a wooden chest (such as one at Position(x=-13.5, y=-51.5)) that collects ore.  
• Transport belt links conveying mined ore from the drill output to storage areas.

### Automation Research Lab
Consists of:
• A lab building receiving automation-science-pack inputs, currently in a no-power state.  
• A supporting electricity network formed by small electric poles that interconnect the lab with power sources, aiding research operations.

### Water Supply System for Power Generation with Updated Steam Engine Placement
Consists of:
• A boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) (status: NO_FUEL) with defined connection points at Position(x=8.5, y=18.5) and Position(x=8.5, y=22.5); its fluid box holds water (200 units at 15° C).  
• Multiple steam engines (generators) intended for power production – several have been repositioned during recent steps:
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=1.5, y=13.5)
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=13.5, y=14.5)
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=19.5, y=14.5)
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=13.5, y=17.5)
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=17.5, y=20.5)
  – Steam Engine at Position(x=11.5, y=20.5)
All steam engines report a NOT_CONNECTED status with warnings such as “not connected to power network,” “no input liquid,” and “no fluid present in connections.”  
• An offshore pump at Position(x=0.5, y=30.5) (status: WORKING) supplies water.  
• Multiple pipe groups (with recent fluid system IDs like 10051, 10059, 10060, 10064, and 10061) form the fluid network that should link the boiler, steam engines, and pump.  
Use-case: This system is designed to feed water into the boiler for steam generation and subsequent power production; however, persistent pipe connection failures have left the network unestablished.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Pipe Connection Failures  
 – Repeated “Failed to connect {'Pipe'} …” errors between the boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) and various steam engine placements indicate alignment or obstruction issues.  
 – Ensure that connection points on both entities are directly aligned and that environmental obstacles are cleared before attempting to connect pipes.

• Placement Validation Issues  
 – Frequent “can_place_entity returned False” messages show that candidate coordinates are unbuildable.  
 – Use API functions to identify the nearest buildable area and confirm sufficient clearance in the intended placement zone.

• Crafting and Inventory Verification  
 – Crafting errors—for example, failing to craft a steam engine due to missing sub-ingredients like iron-plate (which requires smelting in a furnace or a dedicated crafting machine)—highlight inventory and production shortfalls.  
 – Always verify that all necessary items and sub-ingredients are available or produced via the appropriate process before initiating a craft command.

• API Usage and Obstruction Clearance  
 – Errors such as failures in “get_connection_amount” suggest potential misconfiguration of API parameters or lingering obstructions.  
 – Double-check the parameter inputs for connection functions and clear any nearby entities that might block desired placements.
